730178f-a.title: General view - 5th Avenue.
730178f-a.text:
A general view, northeast frog 500 Fifth Ave., N.W. corner of 42nd
Street, showing in the centre the Grcnd Central Building, (45th St.,
between Vanderbilt and Lexington Aves). A view of the East River is
also shown in the background.
June 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

713031f-b.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 5th Avenue.
713031f-b.text:
(1)
Vest 42nd Street, west from a point slightly west of Fifth Ave.
and ahowing buildings on the north side facing Bryant Park. Prominent
building shown in the background is the Bush Terminal Building. Note
its 8-story annex under construction. The left foreground of this
view is the base of the huge Salmon Tower Building.
1916.
Nicholas Savostayanoff.
0ift of Geo. D. Chinn.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A detail of the buildings seen in No. 1 and showing mainly the
18-story Aeolian Hall Building, No. 29-33 West 42nd Street, as viewed
Weo  in a northward direction,from the Bryant Park Mall at the rear of the
New York Public Library (right). To the right of the Hall appears
the 5 storied Central Building; while to the left is Stern Brothers
Department Store.
1916.
Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Cnift of Geo. D. Chinn.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

713026f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713026f-a.text:
WWest 42nd Street, north side, between Fifth and
Sixth Avenue's, showing the West Presbyterian Church.
It was organized in 1829 with 18 members and it's first
house of worship was erected on Carmine Street in 1832.
The structure shown was erected in 1862.
Note the Singhe Tax Club in the adjoining building
at No. 27. The date of this photo is infered from the
presence of the electrified street car tracks.
About 1905
Girt of Urbrock Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED

708779f-a.text:

completed.
Empire State Builoing, completed except for observation tower,
in background.
Taken from N.E. corner of 43rd Street and Fifth Avenue.
DDecember 1, 1930.

708678f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street
708678f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, south from 42nd Street, showing
the old reservoir occupying the avenue frontage. Upon this site
was erected the present New York Public Library Building.
At the left is the spire atop the Brick Presbytertan
Church silhouetted against the old Waldrof Astoria Hotel. To
the right, at the rear of the reservoir is Bryant Park extending
to Sixth Avenue. The hazy outline beyond is the Jersey shore.
1900
From C. Davis Plate Picture Collection
MAY BE REPSODUCED.

No. 500 Fifth Ave., a skyscraper at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street.
Building shown on the left, is the Salmon Towers and it adjoins its
taller sister on 42nd Street.
March 1937.

717904f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street
717904f-a.text:
Bryant Park, eastern and southern portions, seen from the roof of
500 Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, and depicting an early spring snow.
fall, tho day following Palm Sunda7.
In the right center, west of tho fountain, the foundations for the
Federal Hall replica, a part of the George Washington Bicentennial
Celebration. The snow-covered roof of the New York Public Library
is shown in the left foreground.
March 21, 1932.
International News Photos, Inc.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

708794f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street
708794f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 42nd Street, showing traffic
conditions on this main arterial thoroughfare at an early date.
In the foreground, at the N.E. corner of the Avenue and
Enst 43rd Street is the original Temple Beth-El which subsequent-
1y moved uptown. Outlined in the distance are the spires of
St. Patricks Cathedral opposite that atop the Collegiate Church
of St. Nicholas. On the left is the old Bennett Bldg. which stood
for years at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue and W. 42nd Street.
The row of 5 story broAnstones bearing advertising material will
provide a site for the subsequent Postal Life lInsurance Co. Bldg.
The interesting point in reference to this, is that the corner
building was the home of ''Boas'' Tweed.
This photostat is one of a set depicting traffic conditions
and filed under Police Activities and various Fifth Avenue locations
and are evidently part of a group published in the March 11, 1909
issue - page 229.

712993f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street - 5th Avenue
712993f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, east from and including Fifth Ave. The
light colored building on the left, is known as 500 Fifth Ave; the Public
Library is on the right. The Chrysler Building in the background (at the
N.E. corner of Lexington Ave)., overshadows the Hotel Commodore.
1936.
New York Public Library.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

713023f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713023f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Fifth
Ave., showing the new Salmon Tower Building, that replaced Nos. 11 to 27.
The low buildings on the right are the Bristol Building (500 Fifth Ave.)
and four 5-story structures (Nos. 3 to 9) that have today been replaced
by the towering skysoraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave.
1929.
American Photo Service.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717920f-b.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 5th Avenue
717920f-b.text:
Bryant Park, north section, eastward along West 42nd Street. Build-
ings shown are on the north side of West 42nd Street, east from Sixth to
Fifth Aves. Note the structual work at the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave.
This will be the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave. when completed. Views
2 and 3 show a portion of the rear of the New York Public Library which
faces on the Ave. Also note in these, the uncompleted spire of the
Chrysler Building.
May 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

as viewed fromm a vantage point in front of the old reservoir.

708751f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, when site was
occupied by the Henry A. Siebrecht green-house.
At a later period the Bristol Hotel was erected on this site.
As business interests advanced in the mid-town section, the Bristol

1929, to aake way for the Pifth Avenue Sulding, G00). (~. r2 .33

730280f.title: General view - [Manhattan - 42nd Street (East) - Lincoln Building (Northeast) ; 60 East 42nd Street - Vanderbilt Avenue ; General Electric Company ; Grand Central Building ; New York Hospital ; Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.]
730280f.text:
60 E. 42nd Street, (Lincoln Building) south side, west of
Pershing Square (general view northeastward). Merging on the left
nre the Grand Central Building, the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and the
General Electric Building. Numerous Sutton Place apartment struc-
tures are nestled on the right at the .ueensboro Bridge approach.
Beyond same is the white pile of the N. Y. Hospital-Cornell Medical
College. The East River, Welfare Island, Long Island City and the
blended Triborough and Hellgate Bridges are easily identifiable.
1937-8
Alexander Alland
NO REPRODUCTIONS
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume
''Portrait of N. Y.'' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

and replaced by the present (1937) 21-story Bankers Trust Co. Building.

708798f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street
708798f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., east side, north from but not including East 42nd Street,
showing Temple Emanuel, at the N.E. corner of East 43rd Street. The
temple was demolished sometime between 1925 and 193O and on its site was
erected the 40-story structure, Lefcourt-National Building. The congreg-
ation of Temple Emanuel erected a new house of prayer on Fifth Ave.,
at the N.E. corner of East 65th Street. The congregation consists of
the upper social strata of New York Jewry and services are conducted in
English.
Prior to 1925.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

Madison Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
Between 1916 and 1922.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

708793f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street
708793f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from a point slightly
to the south of 42nd Street, showing a procession of
electric cabs and their earlier prototypes, the horse
drawn hansom, silhouetted against buildings on the east
side of this thoroughfare.
The photographers vantage point is in front
of the old reservoir, now the site of the New York
Public Library.
To the left of center is the twin towered
synagogue, Emanu-El. The uncompleted office structure
at the S.E. corner of 45th Street was finished in 1899
and thereby dates this photo. Beyond are the spires
of St. Patrick, St. Thomas, and St. Nicholas Churchs.
1898-9
MAY BE REIRODU1ED

713002f-a.title: Manhattan: 42nd Street (West) - 5th Avenue.
713002f-a.text:
42nd Street, at Fifth Ave., as seen from the Republican Club
(54-56 West 4Oth Street) and across Bryant Park. Shown from left to
richt are, Stern Bros, Aeolian Hall Building (under renovations), Salmon
Tower (newly completed), No's 9 to 3 West 42nd Street inclusive (5-story
brownstones), and the Bristol Building (N.W. corner of Fifth Ave.); the
last two items have been replaced by the building called No. 500 Fifth
Ave. The rear of the New York Public Library is shown at the eastern side
of Bryant Park; the front of which is on the west side of Fifth Ave. This
building extends from 4Oth to 42nd Streets. Notice the absence of sky-
scrapers which appear in this area today.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

708759f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 42nd Street

About 1920.
Cift of E. M. Jenks.
